hints_html:
This is a Riemann sum...

Recall and compare with the definition

\(\int_a^b f(x)\,dx = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{b-a}{n} f\left(a+\frac{i(b-a)}{n}\right).\)
hints_latex:
Recall and compare with the definition

$\int_a^b f(x)\,dx = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{b-a}{n} f\left(a+\frac{i(b-a)}{n}\right).$
hints_raw:
This is a Riemann sum...
Recall and compare with the definition

<math> \int_a^b f(x)\,dx = \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{i=1}^n \frac{b-a}{n} f\left(a+\frac{i(b-a)}{n}\right). </math>
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
We recognize that this has the form of a Riemann sum:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n} f(x_i) \Delta x\end{aligned}\]

We identify

\[\begin{aligned} \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{\pi}{4n}\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} x_i = a + i \Delta x = a + \frac{i \pi}{4n}.\end{aligned}\]

This gives us that

\[\begin{aligned} b-a = \frac{\pi}{4}\end{aligned}\]

Now, notice that the function in question is \(f(x) = \tan(x)\) and so

\[\begin{aligned} f(x_{i}) &= \tan(x_{i})\\ &= \tan\left(a + \frac{i \pi}{4n} \right)\\ &= \tan\left( \frac{i \pi}{4n} \right)\end{aligned}\]

and so we see that we can choose \(a = 0\). This gives us that

\[\begin{aligned} b = b-0 = b-a = \frac{\pi}{4}.\end{aligned}\]

Hence, the integral is

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{\tfrac{\pi}{4}}\tan(x)\, dx\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_raw:
We recognize that this has the form of a Riemann sum:

:<math>
\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \sum_{i=1}^{n} f(x_i) \Delta x
</math>

We identify
:<math>
\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n} = \frac{\pi}{4n}
</math>
and
:<math>
x_i = a + i \Delta x = a + \frac{i \pi}{4n}.
</math>
This gives us that

:<math>
b-a = \frac{\pi}{4}
</math>

Now, notice that the function in question is <math> f(x) = \tan(x) </math> and so

:<math>\begin{align}
f(x_{i}) &= \tan(x_{i})\\
&= \tan\left(a +  \frac{i \pi}{4n} \right)\\
&= \tan\left( \frac{i \pi}{4n} \right)
\end{align}</math>

and so we see that we can choose <math> a = 0 </math>. This gives us that
:<math>
b = b-0 = b-a = \frac{\pi}{4}.
</math>
Hence, the integral is

:<math>
\int_{0}^{\tfrac{\pi}{4}}\tan(x)\, dx
</math>

completing the question.
statement_html:
What integral is defined by the following expression?

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{\pi}{4n} \tan\left(\frac{i\pi}{4n}\right)\end{aligned}\]

(Do not evaluate the integral.)
statement_raw:
What integral is defined by the following expression?

:<math>\lim_{n\to\infty}\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{\pi}{4n} \tan\left(\frac{i\pi}{4n}\right)
</math>

(Do not evaluate the integral.)
